articleContent.title: Chord: 13th in D# (Shape: E)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: 13th in D# (Shape: E)

## Brief Presentation
The 13th chord is a complex and rich-sounding chord that adds color and depth to a musical composition. This particular 13th chord is in the key of D# but can be played using the open E shape on the guitar. It consists of multiple notes that create a lush and harmonically interesting sound.

## Notes and Intervals
The 13th chord in D# (E shape) consists of the following notes:
- Root (1)
- Major 3rd (3)
- Perfect 5th (5)
- Major 7th (7)
- Major 6th (13)

The intervals in this chord are as follows:
- Root to Major 3rd: Major 3rd (M3)
- Root to Perfect 5th: Perfect 5th (P5)
- Root to Major 7th: Major 7th (M7)
- Root to Major 13th: Major 13th (M13)

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The 13th chord in D# (E shape) is often used in jazz, funk, and R&B genres. It adds a sophisticated and jazzy flavor to music, creating a sense of richness and complexity. This chord can be used to add color and texture to chord progressions, particularly in more harmonically advanced styles of music.

## Songs
Here are three songs that use the 13th chord in D# (E shape):
1. **"So What" by Miles Davis**: This jazz classic features 13th chords in various keys, adding to the modal and sophisticated sound of the composition.
2. **"I Wish" by Stevie Wonder**: In this funky R&B hit, you can hear the 13th chord adding depth and color to the harmonic structure of the song.
3. **"Josie" by Steely Dan**: This jazz-rock fusion tune utilizes 13th chords extensively, contributing to the smooth and intricate musical arrangements in the track.

By exploring the 13th chord in D# (E shape) and listening to how it's used in various songs, music students can expand their harmonic vocabulary and understanding of chord voicings.
